For me it was a lack of time and so eating (outside of a restaurant) became simply "refueling" and so I kinda train myself to eat processed food.

Because when I got my own place, I was working 10 hour days six days a week and when you factor in drive time (1 hour) lunch (1/2 hour) morning and evening prep (1 hour), half my day was gone and I still had to set aside 8 hours for sleep, leaving me a grand total of 3.5 hours to live my personal life, thus cooking became a chore that needed to be minimized.

Now if you enjoy chopping, peeling, stirring, prepping, washing, shopping and the rest involved in making a "home cooked" meal, then more power to you but I needed to maximize what little personal time I had and that meant cooking and eating had to be as quick and easy as possible.

Don't get me wrong, I like _eating_ a good meal but I have no interest in all work involved in making it myself.

>>18772909
>Why does this legit have to make the best tasting cup of coffee for me? Is it more forgiving then other methods?
Water boils at lower temperatures the lower the air pressure, with it boiling at something stupidly low, like 12° C in a total vacuum. That's also why baking and cooking instructions also had different temperatures for higher altitudes. With a consumer coffee siphon, the water will boil at something like 93° C or lower, resulting in a better cup of coffee because you don't extract the more bitter compounds in the grounds.

I went looking for an alternative to chinkshit coffee tubes and I've settled on swedeshit spice jars, aka IKEA ÖRTFYLLD
>decently thick glass
>wide enough mouth to fill without a funnel
>lid has a gasket seal (don't know how effective)
>flat bottom so it can stand without a meme wooden base
>large volume
The last point may be a con if you just want single-dose sized containers and don't like wasted jar space. I consider the extra space a nice buffer for any off-gassing from fresh beans and the thick glass doesn't hurt either.
In pic related, the left jar has about 36g of beans while the right jar has 22g which is my typical amount for a doubled-up Aeropress brew.
I have no doubt that if you have peaberry-sized beans, you could fit 45g+ in a single jar.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
pastebin anon here again
Im working on revamping the western brewing instructions, these are meant to be for beginners and Im assuming they will at most rebrew one time
If you can test any of these and give feedback or have other comments let me know
For black tea use 1-1.5 grams per 100ml of water, use boiling or freshly boiled water, brew for 3 minutes.
For green tea use 1-2 grams per 100ml of water, use 70c-75c water, brew for 3 minutes
For green oolongs use 1-2 grams per 100ml of water, use 80c water, brew for 3-4 minutes
for dark or roasted oolongs use 1.5-2.5 grams per 100ml of water, use 90c-100c water, brew for 4-5 minutes
for ripe puer or other fermented teas 1.5-2 grams per 100ml of water, use boiling or freshly boiled water, brew for 5-7 minutes
for young green puer strongly consider gongfu brewing instead, 1.5-2 grams per 100ml of water, use 90c water, brew for 2-3 minutes
for yellow tea? 1-1.5 grams per 100ml of water, use 80c water, brew for 2-3 minutes

>>18771546
Great improvement if only for dropping the multiple steeping stuff. 99% of people aren't even aware tea can be steeped more than once, it simply isn't done except by tea nerds fascinated with the Far East. Some places like Turkey or southern US steep tea for 15+ minutes. Directions shouldn't be totally out of touch with real life culture, typical teabag/sachet suggestions, western vendors, and ISO 3103. Here's the current version for reference
https://cdn.standards.iteh.ai/samples/73224/79469b30ce154460b38ebb10af5565cf/ISO-3103-2019.pdf

Example instructions from Upton: 2.25g 6oz (177ml) 3-4 min.
Vahdam: 2g 180ml 3-5 min.

Lipton stringed teabags contain 2.25g of tea and UK square teabags contain 3.125g. PG Tips has 2.9g. ISO 3103 traditionally used 2.83g based on an old sixpence coin. This goes into a 6-10 ounce sized cup, or 140ml for ISO 3103.
Teabag packaging directions are typically 2-5 minutes. ISO 3103 is 6 minutes for black tea with milk, 3-5 minutes for other types depending on how chopped up it is.
Green tea is fine up to 80-85C and others can use off-the-boil or more precisely 86-90C is ideal. This is based on several papers I can link if you're curious, plus I tested with a thermapen. There's not a lot of nuance. Either the tea has catechins damaged by boiling water (green) or it doesn't.

Also, u guise, keep in mind it's often mixed with milk and/or sugar. Astringency is "body" which is desirable to an extent. Upscale stores unironically offer CTC and African tea. A lot of tea is created without any consideration for drinking it like a Chinaman. It's grown in other countries too.

>If you're not an enthusiast, then why are you here?
A large number of newcomers to the thread get an inkling that tea must taste better than the shitty teabags they have had and come here to find out about how to experience that.
To be clear the problem isint that it encourages you to rebrew the tea, the probelm is that is suggests initial brew times of 2 minutes instead of a more reasonable 3 or even 4, and the reason it does that is so that you can get 3-4 brews out of some black tea leaves. This ends up with a brewing processes that is cumbersome, takes time and heavily reduces accessibility for no actual benifit (unless you are the guy selling expensive tea leaves to people and trying to justify the price by increasing the precieved utility)
Directions calibrated around making the first cup as rich and enjoyable as possible provide the best utility to the most number of people, especially beginners that want to look up some brewing instructions. If someone wants to brew their tea 4x they should be gongfuing it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
just drink the tea retards

how to tea:
bag: soak bag in water for as long as you want
loose leaf western: soak leaf in water as long as you want
gong fu: soak leaf in gaiwan for as short as you want, the more you brew the longer you can soak
grandpa: soak leaf in water, and continually refill the container when you have drank between 50-80% of the water.
general tips:
teabags are generally 1 time use, but some can be steeped more than once
loose leaf tea can generally be used more than 1 time, use them until they dont taste good anymore
water temperature: start with boiling water. some teas are more delicate and will taste unnice if you brew with water that is too hot, if that is the case use water less warm than boiling.
gram to water ratio: some teas are nice with more tea, some teas are nice with less. depending on brewing method you might want more, or less. rule of thumb is short steep = more leaf, long steep = less leaf.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Alright, for the pastebin, shou puerh round two - A Better Shou
8g/300mL 360s 100c
Night and day, you just can't brew really tightly pressed tea without a rinse, this came from a very loose cake and it's extremely obvious. Really rich, thick, a lot of sweetness comes through. No real huigan, but that's kind of what you get with aged shou. It makes it very pleasantl smooth though, no real rough cereal notes or smokiness. A lot of beetroot, very earthy, somewhat mushroomy, but more gentle like button mushrooms, nothing too provacative like chanterelles or porcini. Absolutely perfect winter tea, it's great.
Some of you might be shocked by the high leaf / water ratio and long brew time, but at least try it first. Piling the tea, if it's done right, cuts all the astringency and bitterness of the tea away. You lose a lot of flavor that way, but you gain the benefit of being able to push the tea super hard and get back a lot of flavors you wouldn't reasonably be able to extract from even a well aged sheng. Shou absolutely needs to be brewed hard, that's why it exists. I feel that people are afraid to recommend a radically different brewing style, but it's a radically different tea. I have a theory that the "all shou tastes the same" crowd are brewing it like the rest of the tea they have and drinking dui wei flavored water.
Final addendum, you can't brew rock hard shou like this, it's impossible. You need to rinse it and let it sit, if you try and do a one shot ten minute brew you're brewing it at radically different lengths of times depending on how long it takes to open up. That's how you get shitty mulchy tasting hot water. The tea I brewed yesterday was simply bad, it's thin, insipid, and none of the actual character of the leaf comes through. It needs a hard rinse, to hang out for a while and open up, and then a similar high ratio heavy brew.

Ok, going to test now. Disclosure I'm using a 120ml (4oz) cup and brewing with a brew basket. I will use the same teas for both new and old, but due to it being the dead of winter I am short on supply. I don't have a roasted oolong on hand (drank the last of it a month ago) and I don't have yellow tea because who tf has yellow tea.
>Old Green, 0.5g/100ml, 80C, 2 minutes
>New Green, 2g/100ml, 70C, 3 minutes
Using an Anhui Liu An Gua Pian, 0.6g/120ml and 2.4g/120ml. Fresh leaves for both.
While brewing, the first thing I notice with the new vs the old way is that basket brewing in a cup - the new way packs the leaf to rough about the limit, just barely not peaking over the waterline in the cup. I doubt it’s a problem, but I wanted to note it.
After brewing the new method (right) turned out a more greenish-yellow, while the old (left) turned out a more subdued color. In the picture it looks almost empty, but its a noticeable pale green tint in reality.
The old is very…watery. Tastes like hot water with a hint of tea. The hotter water is drawing out some notes of the Liu An Gua Pian that is desirable. The new method is still very light, but this is also a lighter style of green tea. If requested I may do a sencha to see how it works for a stronger japanese green. The new comes forward a lot more with the nutty chinese green notes and has a floralness that the old method lacks. It doesn’t have any bitterness despite the longer brew time. I think this is clearly and objectively superior to the old way.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18775163
>>18771546

>Old Green Oolong (ball), 1g/100ml, 99c, 2 minutes
>New Green Oolong, 1-2g/100 ml, 80c, 4 minutes
Since the new is a range of 1-2g, and I’m seriously on the last of my bag of oolong, I’m going to brew it at 1.7g/120ml to have enough for the old at 1.2g/120ml
First of all, the new method’s lower heat does not open up the ball oolong effectively, it was barely opening by the end of the 4 minutes, while the old method’s high heat had it opened fully by the end of the brew time. Color turned out similar, seems the old method (left) drew out some more byproduct from the leaf, as it looks slightly oily for some reason. Same bag of tea though, just some standard taiwanese oolong.
First of all, please just gong fu oolong. These both turned out very watery. The old way draws out much more of the floral notes of the oolong, and some honeysuckle and a bit of nuttiness, but overall is a pretty weak cup. Would probably shine when eating some spicy, greasy chinese food like all oolongs do though.
The new method has a bit more penetrating fruitiness, but still is a bit watered down. Kinda has this hard to describe berry note with the tiniest bit of floralness. Its amazing how much the brew actually changes things in oolong. Benefit for the new method is it cooled down to drinking temperature much faster. Its very hard to pick a winner, I genuinely think the new needs a higher brewing temperature to open up the leaf and extract more flavor, and both just need more leaf to water. I’ll edge it for the new because the flavor is more penetrating due to the longer brew time.

>Old Sheng Puerh, 0.9g/100ml, 99C, 2 minutes

This one is unique because we have 2 competitors for the new pastebin. I do recommend you just gong fu this as well though. Using a 2020 Ripe, 1g for old, 2.2g for new, 3.5 grams for alternative for my 120ml cup.

Alternative is okay too, it has the texture of puerh that you’d get with gong fu, but I’m getting more of a muddiness taste and a slight bitterness not present in the others. I’m sorry anon, I think this loses to the new method : (

6g 100ml rolling boil 5s-90s
Starts out sweet and slightly floral, maybe slightly smoky like gunpowder. Then at infuson 3-4 it becomes vegetal, a bit bitter and nutty. Good cha qi. I combined some of infusions 3-5. Complex grassy/forest notes. Infusion 6 is just a softer version of 3+. Most likely has good durability.

I have to say drinking young raws is based and redpilled. Old raws taste like death and destruction (in a good way)

Rum is a highly diverse spirit. Try a jamaican pot still rum, guayana, martinique, etc. You'll find your favorites.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18777782
Here is a good infirmational on a crazy aspect of jamaican rums. The muck pit.

They basically take the leftover rum wash, or dunder, from their distillation and toss it all into a pit in the ground. They add liquid to the fermentation from the muck pit to add a distinct and amazing array of ester flavors. Some may find it disgusting. I find it amazing.

https://cocktailwonk.com/2016/03/days-of-dunder-setting-the-record-straight-on-jamaican-rums-mystery-ingredient.html

If you dgaf about the taste of meat like this then you should consider just not buying meat for yourself altogether. I made that decision -- not an ethical vegetarian but just realized I never gave a fuck about (primarily chicken, pork, and cow) meat and it was a lot cheaper and more interesting to cook primarily with other stuff. To the inevitable shitposters: I'm not forcing anyone to give up their goodies -- I'm saying that if someone clearly doesn't get any extra enjoyment of meat products then they shouldn't pay the extra markup when, say, they'll probably find any of the hundreds of steamed non-meat buns more flavorful and cheaper.

Has anyone in this board grown culinary mushrooms for eating? This is food but I've never seen a thread about it. Let me introduce you guys to the fun of growing mushrooms. It's so easy and this hobby can provide hours of active entertainment.

To start with, I had the idea to try growing oyster mushrooms that I got from the grocery store. These cost about $15/lb here which is quite a scam considering they can be cloned by an average retard. So check this out, all you have to do is take out little bits from the mushrooms with a scalpel and feed them. Then they'll grow into a new organism. I will give more details in subsequent posts.

>>18768748
So what you're seeing in these images is little bits of flesh that I extracted from inside the fleshiest part of the mushroom. The secret that Big Mushroom doesn't want you to know is that you have to do all this in an extremely clean environment. Mushrooms are a fungus, and so is mold, which means that in order to grow mushrooms you need to essentially prepare a perfect environment for mold to grow, but without growing mold. The only way to do this is by physically preventing a single mold spore to come in. So when you open up the mushrooms, do so by ripping them, and then use a flame -sterilized scalpel to carefully get out a piece of flesh. All of this needs to be done inside a still air box, which can be made by overturning a large plastic tote and cutting two armholes so you can do mushroom stuff inside it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18768775
The medium that I have placed the flesh on is malt extract agar. This is essentially a nutrient-rich jelly which is used to fill petri dishes, which is normally used to cultivate funguses and bacteria in a lab environment. I am using small plastic ketchup containers instead of real petri dishes because I'm poor. In order to make these things, you need a few powder ingredients (the nutrients and the agar) and then you mix it with water and pressure cook it for 45 minutes to make sure there isn't a single living organism or spore in the mixture. Then pour it into ketchup containers (inside the still air box) while it's still hot, and let it cool, and it becomes a nutritious and delicious and sterile medium on which you can propagate mushroom clones.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18768809
In the last couple images, and this one, you can see how the mushroom flesh sends out fibers to colonize and eat the agar jelly. It's so beautiful to watch this. The purpose of the jelly step is to make sure that our cultures do not have any contaminants in them. Like I was saying before, this entire game is basically about getting a clean culture which doesn't have any bacteria or mold. The original mushrooms were in the grocery store for God knows how long, getting sneezed on and poked by gross children and bugs, and are covered in contamination. I lost three of five of the original agar cups to bacteria. But you can clone the fuzz from these cups by cutting out a clean and healthy piece and transferring it to a fresh cup. And basically, you can keep doing this indefinitely to make as much as you want, until your cultures are 100% clean.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18768834
Quick background on mushroom biology: mushrooms aren't plants. They are more closely related to humans than they are to plants. Basically, the entire organism is a big fluffy network called the mycelium, which in the wild, lives normally underground or inside trees. And it eats food like animals. The mushroom itself, which you eat, is basically just a sex organ of the mycelium. It sprouts forth from the soil or out the side of a tree to release spores in very certain conditions. But 99% of the organism is this white fluff which is hidden from view.

So what you can do is provoke a bit of a mushroom to grow more of this fluff, which I've just shown you how to do. Then you can feed it until it becomes big, which I'm going to show you how to do next.

Mycelium loves to eat whole grains, so after you have got some clean cuttings isolated on agar, then you're gonna want to multiply it faster by feeding it some grains. Popular and cheap choices include wild birdseed, whole oats, popcorn kernels, and brown rice.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18768876
What you do to make the jars is: soak your grains of choice in water overnight until they're nice and saturated. Then strain, then dump them out onto a few baking sheets and let them dry off until they're dry on the outside. You want the grains to be fully wet on the inside (full of water) but not actually be wet on the outside, so they're just at maximum internal water capacity. That's the perfect hydration level. Then put the grains inside some jars and pressure cook them at 15psi for 90 minutes to kill all the mold and bacteria inside the jars. Then you will have some jars of mushroom food which your mycelium will love to eat.

After the jars are cool, bring them into your still air box and put the mycelium from the jelly cups inside. Cut the jelly into little squares with a flame-sterilized scalpel before you dump them in. Then give it a good shake so the mycelium gets spread around in the grains. This will help it colonize faster.

This is what my jars looked like after a day of the mycelium spreading around the grains.

Once you're at the grainjar stage, assuming you were really careful not to introduce any bacteria or mold into your jars, then you should basically be cooking with fire. The grain spawn generates mycelium at an incredibly fast rate. You can use a flame-sterilized spoon to scoop some colonized grains out of one jar, into a second jar, shake the thing up, and it'll be fully colonized in another week. Keep doing this to have infinite mycelium forever.

The final stage is that the colonized grain spawn will be used to incubate these giant bags, which contain a mixture of 50% hickory sawdust and 50% soy hulls. These ingredients are chosen to replicate the environment of a dead tree, which is where oyster mushrooms actually grow. This step is used to basically stretch your dollar further. You could fruit mushrooms right out of a grain jar, but for a few cents extra you can colonize an entire 6lb block of sawdust and get more mushrooms than you know what to do with. Each jar can colonize like 12 of these bags.

If you guys are interested in this hobby, don't fall for the "kits". You can buy "mushroom grow kits" on the internet which basically come with a small pre-sterilized bag of substrate, and a syringe of liquid mycelium culture for you to inject in there. These things are basically a fun toy or an interesting gift for someone in the office, but they're not close to efficient compared to doing everything yourself. I can make these large 5lb fruiting blocks for about $1.50 each, which will be largely converted into mushroom, whereas the grow kits are basically more expensive than just buying mushrooms at the store. And doing all this stuff is way more fun anyway.

posts.com:
>>18769096
Just reread my own ramblings and I could've elaborate more on the final step. When you're making your fruiting blocks, the best source for sawdust is hardwood pellets used for pellet grills and smokers. You can buy hickory pellets at Lowes for 37 cents a pound. Soy hulls are an agricultural waste product and you can buy it online for even cheaper than that. I think they're normally used to feed pigs. The best recipe for bulk substrate for woodloving mushrooms, which includes oysters and shiitake, is 1 part sawdust, 1 part soy hulls, and 3 parts water, all by weight.

There are some alternative substrates which you can use to varying degrees of success. Oysters can also be grown on a mixture of straw and coffee grounds. Or just sawdust, or just straw.

You also don't need to use these bags, obviously, you can use any container. But these are cheap, large, and transparent. And they're safe to pressure cook, which you'll need to do depending on how nutritious your substrate is. If you're just using pure straw, you can just soak it in water and put it right in the bags, and then dump the grain spawn on top and shake it up. Mushroom mycelium has its own immune system, as it's a complex living organism after all, so it's naturally pretty resistant to mold and bacteria once it's established. You can expose a fully colonized jar to the open air, or dump it in a bag of straw, and it will be fine. But soy hulls and coffee grounds are extremely nutritional and encourage the growth of competitive mold. So with these more effective substrates, you need to pressure cook them just like you did the grain jars.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18769113
There's outdoor cultivation methods which mimic the natural environment much more closely. If you grow mushrooms outside it's pretty similar to composting and you don't need to sterilize anything. However, whether you can do this depends largely on your local climate and what you want to grow. And it's also pretty much a crapshoot and less controlled than what I'm doing here. Like you can get some mushrooms from the grocery store and shred them up, throw them on the ground in your backyard, and cover it with a pile of hardwood chips and sawdust and coffee grounds, and your weather and local humidity is right, then mushrooms are probably gonna grow out of it. But it might be multiple years before you see anything and you won't have huge yield, and you might accidentally grow some other shit you didn't want. Most people in this hobby throw their spent substrate in a pile in the backyard and extra mushrooms keep randomly growing out for many years. But that's only worth it because you might as well do it, I wouldn't rely on that as a reliable farming method.

Another cool thing you can do is to inoculate an entire log with spores or liquid culture from a log colonizing species. I have seen it done where someone gets a whole log, then drills a few holes in it and inseminates the log with mycelium, then plugs the holes and wait for mushrooms to start popping out of the log. On Paul Stamets website he sells mushroom plugs that you can stick right into a log for this purpose. However I've never done this so I can't speak in depth about it.

I paid $78 for my pressure canner from Walmart, but I actually had it from before I started growing mushrooms because I used it to actually can stuff. You can also pressure cook a whole turkey in there which comes out really tender and fast. Honestly it's a neat contraption that's kinda worth having just in general. Other than that I have bought a large plastic tub to use as a still air box, 18 glass jars and 24 big bags, 40lbs of birdseed, agar powder on Amazon, soy hulls and wood pellets. I would estimate probably about $60-80 total for all this stuff, and I still have a lot of consumable material left over. I think my first crop will come out cheaper per lb than the mushrooms I originally bought at the store to clone. Eventually I could produce them for about $1.70 per lb in the best case.

>. I don't know that you'll end up saving much compared to commercial farms
It's incredibly fucking cheap once you get everything running. A really easy process would be
1) Buy approx 1Kg of grain spawn of oyster mushroom mycelium
2) Use 100g and grow 10kg of cloned grain spawn
3) Now you got enough grain spawn (if healthy) to inoculate a shitton of substrate
4) Substrate can be something as cheap as sawdust or coconut fiber if you're in a tropical country
5) Profit????
Most of your costs will be in the initial stage while setting everything up and when you inevitably fuck up. But it's a really fun process and if you succeed you can feel good about yourself for turning trash into food.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18777386
It depends on the genetics as well as how even your sub is. If it's lumpy or uneven, or the casing layer is not the same thickness all over, you're more likely to get fewer larger mushrooms rather than an even canopy of smaller ones. It's just because if a handful of pins form before the other ones, then they're going to get more nutrients and water and the later pins will get less, or won't even bother forming at all.

You can get preposterously huge mushrooms if you cover most of the sub with a garbage bag or something and just cut a small hole where light and fresh air can contact the sub. Basically just forcing an entire tub to only fruit in one small location. It'll put all its nutrients and water into the one mushroom and it'll be gigantic.

But for the record I'm talking about culinary mushrooms. This is a blue board so don't get my thread deleted please.

>>18777451
Yes, that's another species that grows on hardwood. Everything I've posted will theoretically directly apply to those also. Though i have no idea what temperature they like or how long it takes. Basically anything that grows on a tree, you can grow it in a bag of sawdust

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18777785
For a dung-loving and top-fruiting culinary mushroom such as white buttons:

Verm is not a critical component of the substrate in any capacity, but it helps the mycelial network grow by making the sub more airy. It doesn't contain any nutrients. You should use verm mixed with coco coir as the bulk sub. Mix this mixture with the grains to form most of the substrate. And then top it with a layer of just verm+coir about half an inch thick. This helps it retain moisture, protects the grains from contaminants, and makes it fruit more evenly.

posts.com:
How do I improve my efficiency while cooking? I find that most things which aren't simple roasts or cooked-from-frozen end up taking twice as long as they should. It seems very difficult to multitask in the kitchen, which is holding me back and makes it difficult to eat as much homecooked food as I would like.

As a simple example, if I'm making a five-ingredient vegetable stew, consisting of
>onions
>carrots
>leeks
>mushrooms
>peppers
I would brown the onions in some oil and butter, add carrots halfway, add leeks and mushrooms and top up with water and add spices, let it reduce a bit and add peppers to soften before the cooking is completed.
Each step should take about five minutes during which I would prep the next step, but I always exceed this time limit and end up with overcooked onions or seared carrots or rubbery mushrooms or mushy leeks. Only the last step works out perfectly every time, something else is an issue, and all my cooking is like this. I can avoid if I prep everything beforehand, but then I'm just losing even more time because I end up with steps that are too short to leave the kitchen, so while I have a recipe that should take 25 minutes in my head, I can either fuck it up over the course of 40 minutes or take almost an hour to do everything if I prep beforehand.
Am I stupid or slow in some way? This has become quite frustrating, especially because I can't really multitask anything more complicated than some rice-cooker rice or boiled eggs while making a recipe of this caliber

>>18776138
First, practice makes perfect. The more experience you have, the easier it'll be to prep vegetals (and other things) quickly. Beyond that, keep your work area clean. A crowded cutting board is both an accident waiting to happen and an exercise in wasting time being careful to avoid cutting things you don't want to.

At any rate, it's okay to prep things before you start cooking. At the end of the day, it's going to take roughly the same amount of time, and you'll get a better end result out of it. Plus, with experience, you'll figure out how much work you should do ahead of time and how much you should leave to do in parallel with cooking. Any bowls you end up using for veggies are mostly just rinse-and-done anyways.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18776138
the 3 big things for kitchen efficiency are economy of movement, efficient time usage, and efficient tool usage.

economy of movement means youre making the best use of your actions. e.g. rather than picking up a handful of diced onions and dropping it into a pot 4 times, you position your pot under the lip of your cutting board and scoop all of them into it in one motion. the work still needs to be done, but you do less of it by doing it intelligently and minimizing time spent doing it.

efficient time usage means starting long, low-attention tasks early and doing short, high-attention tasks while the previous tasks finish. e.g. setting a pot of water for pasta to boil before you start preparing ingredients for a sauce and letting it come to a boil as you prepare whatever your sauce needs. being able to "stack" tasks based on the time they take and the attention they require will make you spend less elapsed time cooking.

efficient tool usage is key. this generally means using cutting boards and knives for edible-while-raw ingredients first and reserving or using them, then using the same boards for things like meats if you use them. similarly, following recipes that make use of fewer cookware items means you spend less time cleaning. you cant share tools for all dishes, but when you can, its helpful. using tools efficiently also means having the skills needed to prepare ingredients quickly - proper knife skills are a must if you want to move faster, so purchasing cheaper ingredients like root vegetables, onions, and occasionally greens to practice your knife skills on is well worth your time and money, and you can still cook them.

something that ties all three of these topics together is knowing how long certain ingredients take to cook given their size - for a mire poix for a stew or soup, you would typically start by sweating onions lightly, adding the celery and carrots. learning how long ingredients take to cook will let you plan things better.

>>18762636

The minimum requirement for something to be considered a pizza is crust, sauce, and cheese. If you do not have these three ingredients, you do not have a pizza. Knowing this, a pizza that contains all of these ingredients and nothing else, contains 0 toppings. A topping is something that is added ON TOP of the baseline ingredients.

There is no such thing as a cheeseless pizza. Such a dish could be considered an open face tomato sauce sandwich, but it is not a pizza.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18780032
You can make a double stock to get better flavour. Take some meat and fry it in fat. Degrease it. Then pour a small amount of stock and cook it down to a glaze. Repeat this a few times then add the rest of the stock and cook it for another hour or so (or until the meat has released all its flavour). Then strain it. You'll have more essence of the animal than just a bone stock this way.

>>18779867
Salpicão is easy. For a dinner night, use 3 large potatos and 3 large carrots, dice them and steam it foe around 10 minutes until it's somewhat soft but not yet falling apart. Reserve. Now cut 3 chicken breasts into 1inch breasts, oil a pan and fry them quickly on each sice. Sepaeatly, add chicken stock to water, just enough to cover the chicken, add and let is cook lid open. The water will evaporate, now it should be tender so as to allow you to shred it with a fork. Do that, and mix with the vegetables you steamed. Add 2 cups mayo, and half a cup heavy cream, and finally add half a cup, or arouns two sticks of finely diced celery. Test for salt, and garnish with parsley.
This is the base, you can swap chicken for tuna (skips the meat prepration), and also add olives, diced green apple (one unit should be enough for these quantities)
Enjoy anon

>>18779793
If by cooking you mean preparing food according to recipes then the learning curve is almost nonexistent. I learned basic cookery in the 6th grade and have been cooking dinners for my household since.
If by cooking you mean creating flavorful dishes by adapting cooking techniques to an assortment of ingredients that's a lot more difficult. There's a short initial curve where you simply memorize what pairs or balances something i.e. adding sweet to spicy but a much much steeper curve to master to the point where you could take whatever you have for ingredients no matter how esoteric and disparate and combine them to make great food, that takes years and a lot of experimenting to do. One of the dads/possible chomos in my boy scout group ran his own catering company and would always cook on the final day of a campout and never fail to make amazing food from whatever garbage was leftover. Even with a full kitchen and whatever I needed for ingredients I still couldn't make food as good as what that fat wop could whip up on a propane stove from the thin final rations of a scouts pantry. That's masterful cooking but I don't think the two are really the same. It's a production vs synthesis kind of thing.

>>18775548
Sure! Here's a recipe for a bowl of sloppa, in the style of Chef John from Food Wishes:

Ingredients:

2 tablespoons olive oil
1 large onion, diced
3 cloves garlic, minced
2 teaspoons ground cumin
1 teaspoon ground coriander
1 teaspoon chili powder
Salt and pepper, to taste
1 pound ground beef
1 (14.5-ounce) can diced tomatoes
1 (15-ounce) can kidney beans, rinsed and drained
1 (4-ounce) can diced green chilies
1 cup beef broth
1/2 cup uncooked quinoa
1/4 cup chopped fresh cilantro
Instructions:

Heat the olive oil in a large saucepan over medium heat. Add the onion and garlic and cook until the onion is translucent, about 5 minutes.
Add the cumin, coriander, chili powder, salt, and pepper and cook for 1 more minute.
Add the ground beef and cook until browned, breaking it up with a spoon as it cooks.
Add the tomatoes, kidney beans, green chilies, beef broth, and quinoa to the saucepan. Bring the mixture to a boil, then reduce the heat to low and simmer for 20 minutes.
Stir in the cilantro and serve the sloppa in bowls. Enjoy!

>>18775962
I apologize for the oversight! Here's the revised recipe with the cayenne included:

Ingredients:

2 tablespoons olive oil
1 large onion, diced
3 cloves garlic, minced
2 teaspoons ground cumin
1 teaspoon ground coriander
1 teaspoon chili powder
1/4 teaspoon cayenne pepper (optional)
Salt and pepper, to taste
1 pound ground beef
1 (14.5-ounce) can diced tomatoes
1 (15-ounce) can kidney beans, rinsed and drained
1 (4-ounce) can diced green chilies
1 cup beef broth
1/2 cup uncooked quinoa
1/4 cup chopped fresh cilantro
Instructions:

Heat the olive oil in a large saucepan over medium heat. Add the onion and garlic and cook until the onion is translucent, about 5 minutes.
Add the cumin, coriander, chili powder, cayenne (if using), salt, and pepper and cook for 1 more minute.
Add the ground beef and cook until browned, breaking it up with a spoon as it cooks.
Add the tomatoes, kidney beans, green chilies, beef broth, and quinoa to the saucepan. Bring the mixture to a boil, then reduce the heat to low and simmer for 20 minutes.
Stir in the cilantro and serve the sloppa in bowls. Enjoy!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18763939
We do have a fair number of diners around here with roots in the mid-twentieth century but it's hard to find one with small-town charm. Highway diners are often glorified family restaurants and/or truck stops, urban diners are overpriced refuges for drunks after last call, and the New England Greek diners have mostly lost what made them Greek in the best sense. My favorite diner memory is from little place with a forgotten name in a forgotten town on a smaller throughway in upper-state New York. The tuna melt sandwich was solid home cooking, and the hostess/waitress might as well have been your aunt. 100-to-1 it was a family business that is now gone, but it would be fun to try and find it again. We talk a lot of shit about boomers, but they kept a lot of those old joints alive. Fetishized "retro" theme restaurants are usually fake and/or gay (though I do appreciate the decreased likelihood of being keelhauled under a pickup truck by locals who don't like my haircut.)

posts.com:
>>18777152
I'm not a jarring expert so yeah I eat them within a week or two. My process is:
>clear jar until it's as sanit'ry as possible
>boil the veg in the brine until cooked through
>carefully tong the veg into the jar
>pour in the boiling brine until full
>seal

It's not full pasteurization but it's close, but in any case these are quick piggles and not the non-perishable kind. Usually I've polished off the whole batch in 10 days, and I keep them refrigerated

Hey anons. I know this is a long-shot, but I'd really like some help with this...

For the past 10 years, between Christmas and New Years, my mom's sister would send us a frozen cheesecake in the mail from Juniors (they grew up in Brooklyn), and we would have have it over the holidays. A sort of new year's tradition that my entire family was a part of.

In mid-2022, she passed away. I didn't realize how bad this effected my mom because I barely knew my aunt, but she really broke down over the holidays this year. Like, really badly.

Anyway, to keep this short, I'd really like to try and emulate the cheesecake recipe for next year. Any ideas on what recipe to use? I tried a no-bake cheesecake, but that ended up basically being sugar and cream cheese. I'd really like to surprise my mother next new years.

>In Bangkok, customers can't get enough of the latter at Wattana Panich, a noodle soup joint in the trendy Ekkamai neighborhood, where third-generation owner Nattapong Kaweeantawong wants to clear up what he thinks is a popular misconception about his beef soup.

>"Lots of people think we never clean the pot," he says. "But we clean it every evening. We remove the soup from the pot, then keep a little bit simmering overnight."

>It's that little bit, he says, that forms the stock of the next day's soup. So, yes, at least a taste of what you put in your mouth is 45 years old and counting.

>"Since my grandfather's time, we've never really had a set recipe about how much of each ingredient to put in," Nattapong says. "So the person making the soup will constantly have to taste it to know what needs to be added."

>He says some of the ingredients include nearly a dozen Chinese herbs, plus garlic, cinnamon, black pepper and cilantro root. And then there's the beef. He goes through about 150 pounds a day.

>"To make it tender, we cook the beef for around seven hours. We put the whole thing into the pot so it absorbs all the flavors," he explains. "Then after three hours, we take it out and cut it into smaller pieces, then cook it for another four hours."

Plain logic. That pan is like .3 cubic meter, so maybe 450 bowls. If they sell 300 a day, they have a third left of that day's. "Land use" - ranchland is usually in an otherwise empty, useless area. If we were kicking people out of their houses to build cowscrapers this complaint would make any sense.
"Water use" - This is often meaningless. A California almond grower is using a precious resource. A cow in the Mississippi basin is using a worthless one.
"Emissions" - methane decays quickly. The environmentalists are asking us to go off meat and dairy for the rest of time for a one-time savings of a few years of one of subset of emissions.

>>It's expensive right now
>Cost would go down
There's already more than enough demand and production for economies of scale to kick in for plant milk. Costs would in fact only go up as inputs like almonds were hit with more demand.
The fact that cow milk is cheaper is a tiny little hint being whispered in your ear by the market that this infographic is a lie, and processing plant milk is actually more resource-intensive in some ways than milking cows.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18769941
Cars have been doing something similar for a long time, not so much subscription service but paying to "unlock" a feature that's already stock on the car.
For example I had a 2016 Tacoma that was very basic, it had single speed windshield wipers. Which really was weird to me since two speed wipers have been a thing since the fucking 60s. Well I did some research and you can simply replace the windshield wiper switch on the steering column with one that has more settings, you just have to buy one that's less than $50 and switch it out. The wiper motor can do all the speeds, the computer that controls it can do it, it's just one cheap part.

Why would Toyota even make two separate wiper switches? Certainly it would be cheaper to just make one that can fully control them, instead of one that can control them and one that can't when every other part of the wipers is the same. Features that are already included in the vehicle are "unlocked" with a simple switch or relay that's part of an expensive options package.

>>18780159
This is the noodle recipe I use if any of this helps as a guideline.only made it to the T once myself and just tweak it for ingredients I have

Noodle soup:
1.5L Bonito or Dashi stock, 200ml soy sauce, 100ml mirin, 1 tbsp granulated sugar

Noodles:
200g soba noodles, 100g spring onions, 150g kamaboko fish cake (optional), 8 Kelp Pieces (optional), 100g Komatsuna or spinach

Tempura:
8 decent sized shrimps, 1 cup all-purpose flour, sifted, 1 good egg, 3/4 cup ice cold water, 1/4 cup sake, Ice cubes for chilling the water

You combine water and kelp leaving it to soak overnight. pour it into a saucepan then remove the kelp just before it comes to a boil. After lowering the heat add Bonito flakes and simmer for about 30 to 40 minutes. Later strain it with a straining cloth and you'll have kelp broth.

Add rice wine vinegar to a pot and bring it to a boil to let the alcohol evaporate, turn down the heat add sugar and cook until it dissolves. Add soy sauce and heat it at a low simmer so it doesn't burn.

Once it starts bubbling around the rim of the saucepan and you see white foam rising to the surface turn off the heat and skim off the foam.

Finely chop leeks, then mustard spinach should be boiled then cut into bite sized slices, the fishcake should be sliced into small chunks.

For the tempura remove the shell and butterfly the top to remove the digestive track from the fresh shrimp, cut off the corner tips of the tail to remove any liquid. Then rub and rinse the shrimp with a little salt, potato starch, and sake. Dab lightly with a paper towel and prepare the batter, mix the eggs thoroughly with cold water then after adding flour and stirring well coat the shrimp with the batter and deep fry.

Now combine the soup broth with the kelp broth. After boiling the soba and noodles al dente, rinse them under cold running water then drain them. Ladle the broth onto the noodles you've reheated up with the hot water and add your toppings and it's done

If you think you can detect soy milk in cooking, first start by doing 50/50 mixes of soy and cow's milk, and then second admit you're wrong anyway.

For the life of me, the best apples I had were New Zealand Fujis. They used to come in during the spring and were available for a few months until the local early pick crops were ready. Nowadays Fuji are almost all Chinese and no one imports from NZ anymore(and no one is planting them anymore in Canada either) so the quality has declined so much.

On a related note, has anyone noticed that Honeycrisp apples are getting shittier? When they first released they had problems with them being ridiculously big, but they were also consistently fucking amazing, now they've managed to better control size but the quality is all over the place.

As far as stuff I can actually get, I like Pink Lady and Granny Smith.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18780107
brine chicken in buttermilk and cayanne pepper. pat dry and macerate in crushed garlic. three stage coating: 1) flour + salt + pepper + pepper + thyme, 2) dip in egg bath (2 egg + 2 tbsp water) + cayanne pepper + tabasco 3) finally dip in bread crumbs/panko + thyme + cayanne pepper. fry in cast iron skillet being careful not to overcrowd and allow pan to come to temp between batches. using a thermometer can help here.

>>18763936
tater tot "hotdish" (casserole).

it's basically browned ground beef mixed with cream of mushroom soup, corn (optional), green beans (optional), put into a casserole dish with a layer of cheese and tater tots on top. basically it's something you could make when you live somewhere cold and remote where it's winter most of the year, and the only things you can get fresh are beef and dairy. a cuisine based around canned or frozen goods.

it's better than it looks if the tater tots and beef are good. I prefer it without the corn and green beans, though I like vegetables, because the canned veggie flavor permeates the dish. natives prefer it that way apparently.

checked. I think the word "hotdish" is just a midwestern thing, and only Minnesota and North Dakota afaik. but hotdish/casserole culture definitely seems to be a bigger deal here than anywhere else I've lived. it seems like the culture around it goes back to WWI and depression era times of scarcity, when canned foods were novel and popular, and of course because it's cheap and easy to make for potlucks and gatherings (e.g. for church). I'm not from this region originally but it's all interesting to me, and a good casserole is pretty nice. certain other regions in the US I've lived in don't seem to have such distinct regional cuisines.

I want to make a casserole now. we just got like a foot of snow last night and the power was out. any comfy recommendations?

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18779196
Of course! I prefer peanut oil;

Use fresh wings or thaw; frozen will work but the texture won't be 100% and you'll need to be more diligent to maintain oil temperature if your system is not regulated (I used a stockpot and infrared temperature gun for years)
Batch size will depend on your cooking vessel, just don't crowd it too much

Parfry at ~250F for ~22-24 minutes, for larger batches start at slightly higher temperature for ~26 minutes
Remove, separate any stuck-together wings, and dry over a rack and/or paper towels
Fry ~365F for 3.5 minutes, or up to 4.5 minutes for larger batches
Remove and dry over a rack and/or paper towels, let cool at least 30 seconds, toss in your favorite sauce and/or seasonings

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
worked at In-N-Out for five years... still my favorite restaurant in the world. Most folks who have worked in the food industry, especially the fast food or high-volume chain restaurants, can tell you horror stories of dubious food handling or using old/stale ingredients to use up the stock. In my time at In-N-Out, I was shocked in the exact opposite way. In the pass one shift, I saw an associate stocking cheese into the fridge under the grills. He accidentally dropped the block as he was loading, and one corner of the block touched the floor. Manager said throw the entire block out. Mind you, the blocks are double plastic wrapped - each stack of 50 or so slices are wrapped, and three stacks are wrapped together to make a block of about 150 slices. Didn't matter. A few associates split the block up to take home, so it didn't go to waste... but it was never going to the customer.

Half of their restaurants score a perfect 100 on their health inspections. And if a store scores lower than a 90 on any health inspection, it's almost guaranteed termination for the shift manager. Regarding food safety and quality, In-N-Out does not f*ck around.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Simmer it gently to reduce by half, replace the lost volume with coconut milk (5-8% fat) and set aside.
Simmer peeled turmeric roots, peeled young galangal (older is too woody for this dish), garlic, shallots, red small chilli (aka "Thai chilli"), coriander roots and lemongrass core-and-base in a bit of the mixture then blitz smooth.
Mix the paste with fresh powdered coriander seed, cumin seed and Indian caraway seed then fry in coconut oil.
When reduced considerably, add extra firm tofu, stir-gently to coat then top off with the coconut/shrimp (prawn) stock.
Bring to a gentle simmer then add several peeled-and-deveined shrimp (prawns), a handful of fresh coriander leaves and some sliced green finger chilli (aka "green cayenne") then lid the pot and off the heat to allow the prawns to finish gently without over-cooking; meanwhile, cook some rice (this is better served with sticky rice or a steamed type of rice cake called lontong but any rice will do) and serve with fresh sliced limes.
If desired, you may add some vegetables and/or potato in with the tofu. Chopped long beans and chayote are particularly nice.
I left out the candlenuts used in the paste because they're uncommon in foreign markets but if the recipe is still too unfamiliar for you, there're lots of tomato-y Mexican prawn soups that are nice and tom yum has far fewer ingredients and its preparation is less involved than the soup I detailed.

posts.sub: How do I stop being a picky eater?
posts.com: I can't fucking help it. I don't eat most raw foods, and most fruits and vegetables more generally. I can eat them in soup, stew formats, sauces, but not as is. I don't like the texture and the taste. It's been since I was young. Either because of the autism or cerebral palsy. The only ones I always ate were peas, beans. I learned to like a lot of foods over time, like cheese, eggs, sweets, corn. But as for vegetables, I can't seem to like them. I can tolerate some, like carrots, cucumbers. But the problem is that I only put up with it, not actually like it that I'd eat it without social pressure. I'm already 20 and it never changed no matter what my parents tried. Yesterday I just got judged again, this time by the father of a friend for not taking salad. A lot of autists end up vegetarian because they don't like the texture of meat or dairy. Funny that I ended up disliking the category of food most valued and whose refusal is associated with childishness the most. I don't know what to do.

posts.com: As a former picky eater I can say that it's 80% exposure. You have to keep tasting the things that you think you don't like, identify what the ingredients are, which ingredients are tolerable and which are not. This is your baseline from where you can try to imporove things. Do not start with the things you hate, but the ones that are tolerable. Try out different recipes. Cooking also helps when you are being afraid of textures or condiments because you learn what the ingredients are and it lessens the fear of the unknown. The other 20% is genetics, things which you will never like and thats okay.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Our brains are wired to consider food more palatable if the dedicated taste receptors (one of the six basic tastes) for salt are triggered. And in a non-urban world, salt/sodium is a valuable nutrient; the fact we might have it too readily available in the developed world doesn't change that we would DIE on a zero-sodium diet (mind that animal products like meat aren't zero-sodium, and that herbivores tend to love licking salt where they find it!). So our brains have a good evolutionary reason to like salt.

Also, salt actively interferes (negatively) with another basic taste receptor - the receptor for bitterness (which can mean poison both in nature and in the developed world, or at least something we have no use for, eg an alkali). Most aromatic food (think green vegetables or spices) is bitter, and salt both attenuates that perception and balances it making the combined food still desirable for our brain. You end up with an even more palatable food since you can use an aromatic (desirable) and shut out the bitterness (not always desirable) response.

I think most cooklets read it and get frustrated because they want a fool proof recipe that they can follow like a middle school science experiment and then magically have this perfect restaurant quality meal pop out of at the end. I think most people know that salt really isn't that subjective (unless you're an 80-something geriatric with broken taste buds), and that some food is in fact seasoned nicely. The problem is that there's no simple formula because ingredients are always different and sometimes you need to add more salt than other times, and learning how to season your food properly only comes with a lot of experience. Just about everyone can tell if something is bland or if it's overly salty, but most people have a really hard time getting it right in the process of cooking.

For the most part I simply don't believe this is true. There are always outliers, and of course everyone has different preferences, but salt isn't like spicy food, where different people simply experience it at different levels. By and large if you get a bunch of people together with a high enough food IQ and have them try a bunch of different dishes there will be a general consensus on which things are seasoned well and which aren't.

>>18779718
>therefore taste is also fairly consistent
Don't get me wrong. People have different preferences, and some people love salty foods like puttanesca, while other people really like sour things or bitter things. A dish can emphasize one of those basic flavors while still being balanced. On the other hand, if you were to tell a dozen people to grill a steak, saute some vegetables, and roast some potatoes, and they could only use salt and pepper to season everything, I truly believe that there would be a massive consensus as to which things were seasoned properly and which weren't. An experienced cook/chef is going to do a much better job knowing how much salt to add 95% of people are going to agree that their food tastes better despite using the same ingredients.
